data.title: THE ‘VELVET FOG’ RISES: MEL TORME DEAD AT 73
data.meta_description: Mel Torme, the versatile jazz and pop singer and songwriter whose silky-smooth crooning earned him the nickname “The Velvet Fog,” died yesterday at...
data.text:
Mel Torme, the versatile jazz and pop singer and songwriter whose silky-smooth crooning earned him the nickname “The Velvet Fog,” died yesterday at age 73.

Torme died from complications of a stroke he suffered in August 1996, his publicist Rob Wilcox said.

The singer’s fourth wife Ali and five children were by his side at UCLA Medical Center when he died at 1:45 a.m., Wilcox said.

“He was a very special talent, one of the most talented individuals in our business,” said singer Vic Damone. “A composer-musician-arranger. He was so very bright.”

Torme was mourned by friends including Jerry Lewis, Charlton Heston and Hugh Hefner.

“I’ve lost a wonderful friend,” Lewis said. “There could never be anyone to replace Mel, not only as a singer but as a dear friend.”

Torme began his career at age 4 – and was a regular performer at Carnegie Hall and Michael’s Pub in New York until the stroke.

Born in Chicago in 1925 to Russian-Jewish immigrant parents, Melvin Howard Torme toured with comedian-turned-bandleader Chico Marx.

His creamy baritone led him to an early solo career as a romantic crooner – but he yearned to be a jazz artist.

“For a long period I was singing mushy, sentimental songs. I began to be called the Velvet Fog. I never liked it,” he said.

He was nudged back on the jazz track in 1955 by a record exec and became one of the style’s most respected performers.

The multi-talented Torme played piano and drums, arranged most of his own music, appeared in more than 20 movies and was nominated for an Emmy in 1956 for a supporting role in “The Comedian.”

He won three Grammy Awards – best male vocalist in 1983, best male jazz vocalist in 1984 and a lifetime achievement award this year.

Torme was able to move easily between the jazz and pop worlds. He penned more than 300 songs – including “The Christmas Song.”

It was a sweltering summer day when Torme started jotting down thoughts to make him cool: “Chestnuts roasting … Jack Frost nipping …” The song was written in 40 minutes.
